<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```typescript
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "abc/345";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "/", true));
}
```
}

<<<explanation>>>: This code creates a StringTokenizer object with a delimiter of "/" and a strict mode, which means that it will include NULL tokens. It then creates a StringBuffer object to store the tokens as they are extracted from the input string. The while loop continues until the end of the input string is reached, and for each token, it checks if it matches the delimiter. If it does, it adds a space and the delimiter to the StringBuffer. If it does not, it adds the token to the StringBuffer followed by a space and the delimiter. The altStringTokenizer method is called after the StringTokenizer object has been created, which prints out the tokens in a more readable format. The main method creates an input string of "abc/345" and calls the altStringTokenizer method with the getStringTokenizerStrict method, which returns a StringTokenizer object with a delimiter of "/" and a strict mode.
